message: So I think from a "speed of development" perspective, it wins. This is especially true if you know the Java ecosystem.
This is probably a silly example, but in 30 seconds: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/451619/what-is-your-opinion-on-clojure/665673#665673
I really only know elisp, and that's only from a "make emacs do X" perspective.
@justinlilly Because I agree, it looks fairly readable
Right
@ericflow Why did you just star that?
Specifically, you can call out to java libraries fairly easily.
Which I think is a nice feature
i haven't worked with it a lot to determine whether or not that has a huge affect on large programs, but [] and (func + 1 2 3) really breaks that, imo killer, feature
@justinlilly yeah those are nice, i certainly don't mind new atoms to express long-winded-functions-in-common-lisp
so you're using it as a +1 then?
/me is trying to figure out the social norms of this community :-P
right. understood.
Like all networks, they tend to just evolve.
Yeah, I don't think from a code execution perspective it does though
I don't like that they've manhandled CL syntax though
@asenchi howso?
I personally like their thrush operator ->>
Hmm, let me find an example.
http://clojuredocs.org/clojure_core/1.2.0/clojure.core/-%3E%3E  -- I really like that.
hrm. I think I understand.
Yeah, that looks nice
I don't know enough of lisp to have a strong opinion on CL, tbh.
@justinlilly mostly it takes the code as data/data as code and kind of mungles that
http://clojuredocs.org/clojure_core/clojure.core/-%3E -- a similar version of the above thing.
err. -w
I would personally use it as a "remember this link", which would be on the link.
https://gist.github.com/589650
yeah, it is nice.
@ericflo ^^
It is/can be used for both
Sorry to be vague, but like I mentioned earlier, different social norms have cropped up in different groups
@ericflo doest that favorite lead you back to that point in time? Perhaps I should just favorite a comment
I really like that example of clojure code. Fairly readable and interops with java.awt
tbh i am in love with lisp(-like) syntax, wish i had more time to spend with it. Honestly, I really like what pg has done with arc, just wish he'd put more effort in the community and language
